snippet: An all-out civil war in Sudan may be the best way to permanently oust Omar Hassan al-Bashir and his brutal, corrupt government.
abstract: Op-Ed article by author Gerard Prunier asserts that an all-out civil war in Sudan may be the best way to permanently oust president Omar Hassan al-Bashir and his brutal, corrupt government. (M)
lead_paragraph: Addis Ababa, Ethiopia LESS than a year after South Sudan declared its independence, it appears headed for war once again with its northern neighbor, Sudan. At the same time, marginalized northerners are rebelling against the government of Sudan's president, Omar Hassan al-Bashir. The international community has called for a cease-fire and peace talks, but the return of violence is not necessarily a bad thing. Soldiers killing one another in war would be far less devastating than thousands of women and children starving to death while waiting for a negotiated peace that will never come.

headline.main: In Sudan, Give War A Chance
